dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: October 15, 1958. The Radio and Television News Directors Association Annual meeting. We're in the wings of the theater. Standing there alone is Edward R. Murrow. He looks slightly ill at ease. He lights a cigarette... he looks at some notes in his hand as we overhear his glowing introduction by the Mc. Cheers and applause as we walk with him to the podium. A long awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: This might just do nobody any good. At the end of this discourse a few people may accuse this reporter of fouling his own comfortable nest, and your organization may be accused of having given hospitality to heretical and even dangerous thoughts. cuT TO: Close ups of people listening. Smiling. Not aware that this is not to be the comfortable acceptance speech you might hear of a retiring employee getting his gold watch. This will become what will later be called "The Box of Lights and Wires Speech”. One of THE MOST IMPORTANT broadcast journalism speeches EVER. It is an attack on everyone in this room... an attack on himself. And, at this point, it has just begun.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But the elaborate structure of Networks, Advertising Agencies and Sponsers will not be shaken or altered. It is my desire, if not my duty, to try to talk to you journeymen with some candor about what is happening to radio and television. If what I have to say is responsible, then I alone am responsible for the saying of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our history will be what we make of it. And if there are any historians about fifty or a hundred years from now, and there should be preserved the Kinescopes for one week of all three networks, they will there find recorded in black and white, or color, evidence of decadence... escapism, and insulation from the realities of the world in which we live. We are currently wealthy, fat, comfortable and complacent. We have a built in allergy to unpleasant or disturbing information. Cur mass media reflect this. But unless we get up off our fat surpluses and recognize that television in the main is being used to distract, delude, amuse and insulate us, then television and those who finance it, those who look at it and those who work at it, may see a totally different picture too late.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: The Reed Harris hearing demonstrates one of the Senator's techniques. Twice he said, “The American Civil Liberties Union was listed as a subversive front.” The Attorney General’s list does not and never has listed the ACLU as subversive, nor does the FBI, or any other federal government agency. And, the ACLU holds in it’s files, letters of commendation from President Truman, President Eisenhower and General MacArthur. The rest of MURROW’S speech will be intercut with close- ups of all our players. Sitting silently at home, in the control room, the newsroom, Paley's office, at home with Shirley Wershba. MURROW (CONT’D) Earlier, the Senator asked, “Upon what meat does this our Caesar feed?” Had he looked three lines earlier in Shakespeare's “Caesar” he would have found this line which is not altogether inappropriate: “The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars but in ourselves.” No one familiar with the history of this country can deny that congressional committees are useful. It is necessary to investigate before legislating, but the line between investigating and persecuting is a very fine one; and the Junior Senator fron Wisconsin has stepped over it repeatedly. We must not confuse dissent with disloyalty. We must remember always that accusation is not proof and that conviction depends upon evidence and due process of law. We will not be driven by fear into an age of unreason, if we dig deep in our history and our doctrine, and remember that we are not descended from fearful men, not from men who feared to write, to speak, to associate and to defend the causes that were for the moment unpopular. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURROW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We proclaim ourselves as indeed we are, the defenders of freedom wherever it continues to exist in the world; but we cannot defend freedom abroad by deserting it at home. The actions of the Junior Senator from Wisconsin have caused alarm and dismay amongst our allies abroad and given considerable comfort to our enemies. And, whose fault is that? Not really his. He didn’t create this situation of fear, he merely exploited it, and rather successfully. Cassius was right. “The fault dear Brutus is not in our stars but in ourselves.” Good night. And Good luck. cur TO: INT. “SEE IT NOW" SET MURROW looks to FRIENDLY who is lying at Murrow’s feet. They look to the control room...HEWITT shrugs his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLENBECK

dialogues.speaker: HOLLENBECK, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOLLENBECK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: as if all reasonable people took a plane to Europe and left us behind... trying to make sense out of... insanity... I was always an optimist... really... I always felt like things would work out... half full...

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: I believe that... it‘s the beauty of all this... we designed it so we can fix it... Jefferson built it into the Constitution...

dialogues.speaker: HOLLENBECK
dialogues.text: I was talking about my divorce... They smile.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: So was I... & sad smile

dialogues.speaker: HOLLENBECK

dialogues.speaker: HOLLENBECK

dialogues.text: So am fT. A sad grin.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLENBECK

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Sorry, Don. Hollenbeck starts to leave, he stops and turns to Murrow.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLENBECK

dialogues.text: {Talking too loud into the ceiling lamp) IF IT’S OKAY WITH YOU, SENATOR.

dialogues.text: Annie Lee Moss is being questioned by a Senator Symington.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR SYMINGTON
dialogues.text: Have you ever had any information that you received in your job that you passed on to anybody about these codes?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE LEE MOSS
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR SYMINGTON
dialogues.text: Did anybody ever ask you to, for any of that information?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE LEE MOSS
dialogues.text: No, sir. If they had, I would have reported ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR SYMINGTON
dialogues.text: You would have reported them?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE LEE MOSS
dialogues.text: I certainly would have.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR SYMINGTON
dialogues.text: Has anyone ever asked you to join the Communist party? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE LEE MOSS
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR SYMINGTON
dialogues.text: Has anybody ever asked you to join any organization of any kind that you thought might be against the best interest of the United States?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE LEE MOSS
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR SYMINGTON
dialogues.text: What are you living on now? Have you got any savings?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE LEE MOSS
dialogues.text: No, siz.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR SYMINGTON
dialogues.text: You haven't?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE LEE MOSS
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR SYMINGTON
dialogues.text: If you, uh, uh, uh, don’t get work, uh, pretty soon, what are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE LEE MOSS

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR SYMINGTON
dialogues.text: Going down to welfare.

dialogues.text: HEAR MORE OF MURROW’S VOICEOVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie Lee Moss is now being questioned by Roy Cohn and Sentator McClellan.

dialogues.speaker: ROY COHN
dialogues.text: t have no further questions of this witness at this time. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROY COHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can say this, we have the testimony of Miss Markward, the undercover agent for the FBI, stating that Annie Lee was, was a member, a dues-paying member of the Communist Party, uh... the Northeast Club of the Communist Party. We have corroboration of that testimony by another witness who was called before the committee and gave their sworn statement to the effect that she also knew Mrs. Moss as a member of the Northeast Club of the Communist Party.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR MCCLELLAN
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Chairman, I‘d like to make... we're making a statement here against a witness who has come and submitted to cross- examination. Now, she’s already lost her job. She’s been suspended because of this action. I’m not defending her. If she’s a Communist, I want her exposed. But, to make these statements as we've corroborating evidence that she is a Communist. Under these circumstances, I think she’s entitled to have it produced here in her presence and let the public know about it and let her know about it. There is applause. SENATOR MCCLELLAN (CONT’D) I don’t like to try people by hearsay evidence. More applause.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR MCCLELLAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd like to get the witnesses here and try ‘em-- by testimony, under eath.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN MUNDT
dialogues.text: The, wh, chair will rule that the comment of Mr. Cohn be stricken from the record.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: e.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR MCCLELLAN
dialogues.text: Well, I didn’t ask that. I didn't ask that, Mr. Chairman.

dialogues.speaker: CHAIRMAN MUNDT
dialogues.text: +e. executive session whether we should try to, uh, produce a witness in public because the FBI may have her undercover and we don’t want to, uh-

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR MCCLELLAN
dialogues.text: You can’t strike these statements made by counsel here as to evidence that we're having and withholding. You cannot strike that from the press nor from the public mind once it’s planted there. That’s the, that is the, uh, the evil of it. And I don’t think it’s fair to a witness, to a eo citizen of this country, to bring . ‘em up here and cross-examine ‘em. Then when they get through say, “We've got something, the FBI has got something on you that condemns you.” It is not sworn testimony, it's convicting people by rumor and hearsay and innuendo. Applause. cur TO:

dialogues.text: INT. “SEE IT NOW” SET This scene will be built with a lot of very tight close ups of crew and reporters. Everyone is very aware of their vulnerability. Cameramen glancing at one another. Stage Manager focusing on the monitor. Right now it’s silent as they wait for MURROW to arrive. oo We pull Ed in a close up as he enters into the room an e sees the film canisters. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HEWITT
dialogues.text: Ed, it’s twenty eight minutes. I could clip a little off the end for you to have time to...

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: I think we have to leave it alone, Don. He starts tearing out pages.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Very smart, no time for comment... when did it come in?

dialogues.speaker: HEWITT
dialogues.text: Ten minutes ago. We put it up, IT saw the first couple of minutes, you're right.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Coming after me? HEWITT nods. MURROW (CONT‘D) doe, have you seen the latest polls?... The most trustworthy man in America is Milton Berle.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Fred.

dialogues.text: What say we grab a little dinner after the show? The “21 Club”?

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: sure. Ha sits noticing The Boys. They give little waves, MURROW acknowledges them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURROW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What‘re they here for? “The Monkey and the Bell” show is on stage three.

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Who's their first guest? The loudspeaker ~ “Thirty seconds to Air”

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: After tonight, I hear it’s you. They smile. FRIENDLY (CONT ‘D) Look, there’s nothing fun about this one. You’ve just gotta put your gloves down, stick your chin out and just take it for a whole round. Next week's our round.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: If I make it up off the mat. MURROW takes out a cigarette, FRIENDLY lights it. Loudspeaker - “Twenty seconds to air“

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: You will.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Did you see the latest polls, Milton Berle’s the most trusted man in America... They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: You already did this joke for me...

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: L’ll get Berle on the line. Loudspeaker - “Ten seconds” MURROW sits there again in silence. The weight of the world sitting there with him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: In five, four, three, two... He points to MURROW. We come up on the monitor as MURROW speaks directly at us.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: One month ago tonight we presented a report on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. We labeled it as controversial. Most of that report consisted of words and pictures of the Senator. At that time, we said if the Senator believes we have done violence to his words er pictures, if he desires to speak, to answer himself, an opportunity would be afforded him on this program. The Senator sought the opportunity, asked for a delay of three weeks because he said he was very busy and he wished adequate time to prepare his reply. We agreed. We placed no restrictions on the manner or method of the presentation of his reply and we suggested that we would not take time to comment on this program. Here now is Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Junior Senator from Wisconsin. MeCarthy begins. As he delivers his rebuttal we will cut to various places that it is airing. For the moment we’re right on MURROW as he watches.

dialogues.speaker: MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: Good evening. Mr. Edward R. Murrow, Educational Director of the Columbia Broadcasting System, devoted his program to an attack on the work of the United States Senate investigating committee and on me personally as its Chairman. Now, over the past. four years, he has made repeated attacks upon me and those fighting communists. Now, of course, neither Joe McCarthy nor Edward R. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: e@ MCCARTHY (CONT'D) Murrow is of any great importance as individuals. We are only important in our relations to the great struggle to preserve our American liberties. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PALEY watches in silence.

dialogues.speaker: MCCARTHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now ordinarily, I wouldn‘t take time out of the important work at hand to answer Murrow. However in this case I felt justified in doing so because Murrow is a symbol, the leader and the cleverest of the jackal pack which is always found at the throat of anyone who dares expose individual communists and traitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. JOE & SHIRLEY WERSHBA’S NY APT. Shirley watches. MCCARTHY (CONT’D) I am compelled by the fact to say to you that Mr. Edward R. Murrow, as far back as twenty years ago was engaged in propaganda for communist causes. For example, the Institute for International Education of which he was the Acting Director, was chosen to act as a representative by a Soviet agency to do a job which would normally be done by the Russian Secret Police. Back to MURROW on the set. MCCARTHY (CONT‘D} Mr. Murrow sponsored a communist school in Moscow... @ This speech will continue but we'll hear MURROW and FRIENDLY talking. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: e.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: When the politicians complain that TV turns the proceedings into a circus, it should be clear that the circus was already there, and that TV has only demonstrated that not all the performers are well trained.

dialogues.speaker: PRIENDLY
dialogues.text: We've got him, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: If he led with his best.

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: He led with his best. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: MCCARTHY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, Mr. Murrow, by his own admission, was a member of the IWW, that’s the Industrial Workers of the World, a terrorist organization cited by an Attorney General of the United States... cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s empty. McCarthy's voice echoing.

dialogues.speaker: MCCARTHY
dialogues.text: Now, Mr. Murrow said on this program and I quote, he said, “The actions of the Junior Senator from Wisconsin have given considerable comfort to the enemy” MURROW walks into the hall followed by FRIENDLY, WERSHBA, MACK, they walk toward us as the speech continues. MCCARTHY (CONT‘D) That is the language of our statute of treason. If I am giving comfort to our enemies, J] ought not to be in the Senate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MCCARTHY (CONT’D) If on the other hand, Mr. Murrow is giving comfort to the enemies, he ought not to be brought into the homes of Americans by the Columbia Broadcasting System. As they exit we stay on the empty hallway. We fade to black as McCarthy drones on.

dialogues.speaker: LIQUID OR SOMETHING WE FIND IN THE ARCHIVES...
dialogues.text: INT. “SEE IT NOW” SET We are on the set of “See it Now” as MURROW addresses us directly.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Last week, Senator McCarthy appeared on this program to correct any errors he might have thought we made in our report of March 9th. Since he made no veference to any statements of fact that we made, we must conclude that he found no errors of fact. He proved again that anyone who exposes him, anyone who dees not share his hysterical disregard to decency and human dignity and the rights guaranteed by the Constitution must be either a Communist or a fellow traveler. I fully expected this treatment. The Senator added this reporter's name to a long list of individuals and institutions he has accused of serving the communist cause, His proposition is very simple: Anyone who criticizes or opposes McCarthy's methods must be a Communist. And if that be true, there are an awful lot of Communists in this country. For the record, let’s consider briefly some of the Senator’s charges. He claimed but offered no proof that I had been a member of the Industrial Workers of the World. That is false. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURROW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was never a member of the IWW, never applied for membership.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cut to the control booth, HEWITT and company watch on as the broadcast continues.

dialogues.speaker: HEWITT
dialogues.text: Ready two... hold it...hold... take two... tell ‘em Ed. MURROW (CONT’D) The Senator charged that Professor Harold Laski, a British scholar and politician dedicated a book to me. That's true. He is dead. He was a Socialist, I am not. He was one of those civilized individuals who did not insist upon agreement with his political principles as a pre-condition for conversation or friendship. I do not agree with his political ideas. Laski, as he makes.clear in the introduction, dedicated the book to me not because of political agreement but because he held my wartime broadcast from London in high regard; and the dedication so reads.

dialogues.speaker: HEWITT
dialogues.text: Ready on one... closer, Charlie... take one... cUuT TO: INT. “SEE IT NOW” SET Again MURROW addresses us directly.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I believed twenty years ago and I believe today that mature Americans can engage in conversation and controversy, the clash of ideas, with Communists anywhere in the world without becoming contaminated or converted.

dialogues.speaker: MORE
dialogues.text: ‘ ) (CONTINUED)  7i.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: MURROW (CONT ‘D) I believe that our faith, our conviction, our determination are stronger than theirs and that we can compete and successfully, not only in the area of bombs but in the area of ideas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As PALEY watches on a television. INT. “SEE

dialogues.speaker: MURROW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have worked for CBS for more than nineteen years. The company has subscribed fully to my integrity and responsibility as a broadcaster and as a loyal American. I require no lectures from the junior Senator from Wisconsin as to the dangers or terrors of Communism - having watched the aggressive forces at work in Western Europe.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: IT NOW’ SET

dialogues.speaker: MURROW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Having had friends in Eastern Europe butchered and driven in exile, having broadcast from London in 1943 that the Russians were responsible for the Katyn Massacre - having told the story of the Russian refusal to allow allied aircraft to land on Russian fields after dropping supplies to those who rose in Warsaw and then were betrayed by the Russians. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murrow’s team watch and smoke.

dialogues.speaker: WERSHBA
dialogues.text: (Quietly) Go Ed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: And having been denounced by the Russian radio for these reports. I cannot feel that I require instruction from the Senator on the evils of Communism cur TO: INT. “SEE IT NOW” SET MURROW addresses us directly. MURROW (CONT’D) Having searched my conscience and my files, I cannot contend that T have always been right or wise but, I have attempted to pursue the truth with some diligence and to report it, even though as in this case I had been warned in advance that I would be subjected to the attentions of Senator McCarthy. We shall hope to deal with matters of more vital interest to the country next week. Good night. And good luck. We go to a commercial. As we hear it play, we see Murrow stand up. He shakes people’s hands, there are some pats on the back... not victorious... not afraid... simply a job well done. Murrow looks over to Friendly who lights Murrow’s cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: That ought to hold him.

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: Are you a gambling man?

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Just with your career.

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: {smiles} Not just mine... He nods in the direction of Wershba, Zousmer, Aaron and Beck, smoking in the back of the stage. Murrow waves to his boys and they wave back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: We hear the song “How High The Moon” under this shot- cur To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It‘s a couple of hours till air time. ELLA FITZGERALD is rehearsing “How High the Moon." In the background MURROW is seated in his easy chair, there is a small table for his ash tray. A few people are milling about preparing for the show. Murrow talks to TED CHURCH, a CBS executive. Church reads from the New York Times.

dialogues.speaker: CHURCH
dialogues.text: "In the last analysis, the Senator was perched on the television high dive and all prepared to make a resounding splash. He jumped beautifully, but neglected to check first where he was going to land. It must have been something of a shock to discover that Mr. Murrow had drained the water out of the pool.”

dialogues.speaker: CRURCH MURROW
dialogues.text: Jack Gould... yeah, the Jesus. Is that the Times? Times. Gould?

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: He’s a hell of a writer, I‘ll tell you that. You should hire him away from the Times... Friendly enters the stage and walks toward them.

dialogues.speaker: CHURCH
dialogues.text: Well, Stanton'’s got a public opinion survey that Elmo Roper put together that says that 33% of households believe McCarthy proved you're a commie...

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Only 33%? (to Priendly as he approaches ) Hey Fred, did you hear... Radulovich got reinstated... Ted, where's that Radulovich letter?

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: Listen, Ed...

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: We're a hit... up there with Howdy Doody.

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: Hold on Ed. Ella continues to sing in the background as the two men look at each other. Fred says something to Murrow that we can’t hear. A look of disbelief spreads across Murrow's face. Friendly then hands the note to confirm. This sits with two men as Murrow gets up and walks off of the set and into the hall. Ella continues to sing which will score the rest of the scene. Over these scenes we will also hear the voice of Joe Wershba.

dialogues.speaker: WERSHBA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: “Don Hollenbeck was one of the most prominent members of the CBS lefties. And, he hewed to its incipient pink line without deviation.” cur TO: INT. DON HOLLENBECK’S APARTMENT Hollenbeck alone, is taking towels and placing them along the baseboards of his one room apartment.

dialogues.speaker: WERSHBA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "He was a reactionary leftist. He drew assignments which paid him lush fees, pink painting his news items and analysis always with a steady left hand.” cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a close up of Murrow as he walks down the hallway continuing his exit from Person to Person... the pain on his face for all to read. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WERSHBA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: “Hollenbeck was a graduate of several suspicious training posts. He was with the Office Of War Information when it was loaded with commies.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friendly just sits there re-reading the note.

dialogues.speaker: WERSHBA
dialogues.text: “He did a stretch as a top editor of the commie-laden newspaper PM, whose staff was infiltrated slyly by a slew of sinister types not equalled this side of the daily worker.” cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Hollenbeck turn up the gas on his oven but not Light it. his chair He leaves the oven door open and sits back in to wait for his long needed sleep.

dialogues.speaker: WERSHBA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: "The fact of Newscaster Don Hollenbeck's suicide yesterday does not remove from the record the peculiar history of the leftist slanting of news indulged consistently by the Columbia Broadcasting System.” Ella’s song ends. It’s silent. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friendly sits silently on the set. cut TO:  76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

DON HOLLENBECK’S APARTMENT TV light flickers a test pattern and the familiar high pitched tone of a network that has signed off for the evening. Slumped in his chair in the shadows, is Hollenbeck. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: WERSHBA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: “Hollenbeck was what most astute students of CBS's strange and questionable new methods considered ‘typical of its newscasters’”... Beat WERSHBA (V.0.) (CONT’D) «+. by Jack O'Brian. They sit in silence. scoTT (Quietly) What time is it?

dialogues.text: Nine-forty. scorr He wrote that... not twelve hours after Don was dead... Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The son of a bitch. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MACK
dialogues.text: Let’s see what we can find on Jack O‘Brian. They sit there.

dialogues.speaker: WERSHBA
dialogues.text: And then, what are we?... Don Hollenbeck had a troubled marriage... and he died... he had the decency not to leave a note. More silence. WERSHBA (CONT’D) ... And because of that no one will ever remember Jack O'Brian. Wershba leans over and turns up the sound on a TV where Murrow gives a last minute obituary about Hollenbeck. We watch it with the boys.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: One of the best programs I ever heard was called “CBS Views The Press”. A great many people liked it, some didn't, but no one ever said it was anything but honest. It was the work of an honest reporter. Don Hollenbeck. He also worked occasionally on “See It Now”. He did the 11 PM News over some of these stations. He had been sick lately and he died this morning. The police said it was suicide. Gas. Not much of an Obit... but, at least we got our facts straight... and it was brief. And, that’s all Don Hollenbeck would have asked. Good Night. And, Good Luck. Over black we read: “At long last have you no sense of decency”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WERSHBA is running... we're close on his face as he navigates the corners. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED

Murrow and the crew stay fixed on the hearings, as Judy drones on we listen to the famous fight between Welch and McCarthy ending in the line "at long last sir have you no sense of decency" Natalie enters and passes Murrow a note and starts to exit.

dialogues.text: Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: WERSHBA
dialogues.text: Is there a problem, Ted?

dialogues.speaker: CHURCH
dialogues.text: I want to ask you both a question, put I don’t want you to answer it. dust consider it. I know you two are married... They both just sit there looking straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: CHURCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everyone knows... that’s not my question... in the next few weeks I have to lay a couple of people off... we're making some significant cuts across the board. I wanted you to know that. Because if you have any intention, in the near future, of starting a family, I would say to you, that you could save someone else from being fired. I’m asking you to consider making this decision a little easier. I don’t need an answer now. Just think about it. Church stands and leaves. Joe and Shirley just sit there. after a few beats they start to slowly quietly laugh. There is a melancholy to this moment. Joe reaches inte his pocket, pulls out his wedding ring and places it on his finger, Shirley does the same.

dialogues.speaker: WERSHBA
dialogues.text: Well, Mrs. Wershba... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: We're going to miss you around here, Joe. They stand to leave.

dialogues.speaker: WERSHBA
dialogues.text: I'll pack my things.

dialogues.speaker: SHIRLEY
dialogues.text: I think it’s for the best. As they exit. Finally.

dialogues.speaker: WERSHBA
dialogues.text: Everybody knew.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. PALEY’S WAITING ROOM Friendly is seated on the couch as Murrow walks in. Murrow walks over and sits down next to Friendly.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Uh Oh Fred smiles and the two just sit in silence, then we hear....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paley is seated at his desk, across from him sit Murrow and Friendly.

dialogues.speaker: PALEY
dialogues.text: The problem isn’t simply that you‘ve lost your sponsor. With Alcoa, "See it Now” still loses money.

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: The fee is fifty-thousand. And last week's show we did for less than the fee.

dialogues.speaker: PALEY
dialogues.text: Fred, you're speaking beyond your competence. . (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: e, el.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW PALEY
dialogues.text: We’ll find another “$64,000 Question” brings sponsor... we can certainly in over eighty-thousand in find someone who wants sponsors and costs a third CO... of what you do.

dialogues.speaker: PALEY
dialogues.text: Ed. I’ve got Tuesday night programming that’s number one. People want to enjoy themselves. They don’t want a civics lesson.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Well what do you want Bill?

dialogues.speaker: PALEY
dialogues.text: I don’t want a constant stomach ache every time you do a controversial subject.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: I’m afraid that's the price you have to be willing to pay.

dialogues.speaker: PALEY
dialogues.text: Careful Ed. Let's walk carefully through these next few moments...

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: But the content of what we‘re doing is more important... than what some guy in Cincinnati...

dialogues.speaker: PALEY
dialogues.text: ..-What you‘re doing Ed. Not me. Not Frank Stanton. You.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: "CBS News”, “See it Now” all belong to you.

dialogues.speaker: PALEY
dialogues.text: You wouldn’t know it.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: ie it credit you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Silence. 82. (2)

dialogues.speaker: PALEY
dialogues.text: I never censored a single program, I hold on to affiliates who wanted entertainment from us, I’ve fought to keep our license with the same politicians that you were bringing down, and I never said no to you. Never.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: I would argue that we’ve done well by one another. I would argue that this network is defined by what the news department has accomplished. I would also argue that never saying no, is not the same as “not censoring.”

dialogues.speaker: PALEY
dialogues.text: Really. Well you should teach journalism... You and Mr. Friendly.

dialogues.speaker: PALEY
dialogues.text: Let me ask you this: Why didn’t you correct McCarthy when he said that Alger Hiss had been convicted of treason? He was only convicted of perjury. You corrected everything else. Did you not want the appearance of defending a known communist? I would argue that everyone censors... including you.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: What do you want to do, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: PALEY
dialogues.text: I’m going to take your show from half an hour to an hour. But, it won't be a weekly program. And, it won’t be Tuesday night.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: When would it be?

dialogues.speaker: PALEY
dialogues.text: Sunday afternoon. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: How many episodes?

dialogues.speaker: PALEY
dialogues.text: Five.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Why don’t you just fire me?

dialogues.speaker: PALEY
dialogues.text: E don't think it’s what either of us wants. Silence. PALEY (CONT’D) You owe me five shows.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: You won’t like the subject matter. Murrow and Friendly get up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: PALEY
dialogues.text: Probably not. Fred, I’li need you for a moment. We follow Murrow out to the hall where he waits for Fred. We stay on his face for a few moments and then we hear Fred approach. They walk down the executive hallway.

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: He wants me to lay a few people off.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: I’m sure.

dialogues.speaker: PRIENDLY
dialogues.text: Let’s do the first show about the downfall of television.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: The Senate's gonna vote to censure MeCarthy tomorrow...

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: What happens then? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: He sits in the back row...

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Right... they keep him in the Senate... they don’t kick him out.

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: No... he stays... he‘ll just lose all of his power.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: He's already lost all his power... now it’s just teaching him a lesson. This sits with the two old friends. They start to walk to the elevators.

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: Well, we might as well go down swinging. We'll do the story about the migrant farm workers... make a couple of enemies.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Have you seen the latest polls Fred? The most trusted man in America is Milton Berle.

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: See, maybe you should have worn a dress.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Works for Hoover.

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: Shhh... he’s listening.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: How does scotch sound?

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: Scotch is good.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Did you know Joe and Shirley were married?

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: Sure. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: Did everybody know?

dialogues.speaker: FRIENDLY
dialogues.text: Pretty much... We pass a bank of monitors that start on Milton Berle. We pan to the next monitor and it’s Howdy Doody. To the next and it's Kookla Fran and Ollie. The next one is Murrow giving the last of his “Box of Lights and Wires” speech. We move in on the monitor.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW
dialogues.text: I began by saying that our history will be what we make it. If we go on as we are, then history will take its revenge, and retribution will not limp in catching up with us.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just once in a while, let us exalt the importance of ideas and information. Let us dream to the . extent of saying that on a given e Sunday night, the time nermally occupied by Ed Sullivan is given over to a clinical survey on the state of American education, and a week or two later, the time normally used by Steve Allen is devoted to a thouroughgoing study of American policy in the Middle East. Would the corporate image of their respective sponsors be damaged? Would the stockholders rise up in their wrath and complain? Would anything happen other than a few million people would have received a little illumination on subjects that may well determine the future of this country and therefore the future of the corporations. cur Ta:

dialogues.speaker: INT, CHICAGO THEATER
dialogues.text: on Back on our original set.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To those who say people wouldn't look, they wouldn’t be interested, they’re too complacent, indifferent and insulated, I can only reply- there is, in one reporter's opinion, considerable evidence against that contention. But even if they are right, what have they got to lose? Because if they are right, and this instrument is good for nothing but to entertain, amuse and insulate, then the tube is flickering now and we will soon see that the whole struggle is lost.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: We cut back to the monitors. As Murrow finishes we pan around to other monitors. Watching the history of TV played out in sound bites. We see: Kennedy being shot, John John’s salute, Vietnam, Man landing on the moon, Lucille Ball, Archie Bunker, Watergate, Laugh-In Carter with Begin and Sadat, The Hostages in Iran, Sixty Minutes, Reagan’s - “Mr. Gorbachev tear down this wall.”, Inside Edition, (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The O.J. Chase, Michael Jackson, Victorias Secret, Bill O’Reilly..., And the camera moves in on a single shot of Jerry Springer as people are throwing chairs and chanting, “Jerry!”

dialogues.speaker: MURROW V.O
dialogues.text: This instrument can teach, it can illuminate; yes, and it can even inspire. But it can do s0 only to the extent that humans are determined to use it to those ends. We freeze on the frame as we see a fist-fight break out

dialogues.speaker: MURROW V.O, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Otherwise, it is merely wires and lights in a box. We fade to black.

dialogues.speaker: MURROW V.O, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .--Good Night. And, Good Luck.
